Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project addresses the lack of commonality which has historically plagued the robotics research community due to the lack of sharable code. Robotics is an experimental endeavor, and code, the software that is written to control the robot, is at the core of any research or development effort. Innovation occurs best when the community builds on each others' accomplishments and robotics has progressed to the point that both researchers and developers can benefit from a shared, high-quality, common software toolbox to build useful and commercially viable applications with a minimum of duplicated engineering effort. This software is part of an open source "robotics commons": a shared resource from which all can benefit and to which are can contribute. To build this commons, this proposal begins with ROS (Robot Operating System), an open software platform comprising libraries and tools that facilitate building and running robot applications. Designed for both robotics researchers and application developers, ROS is already widely used around the world in classrooms, labs, and companies. Hence, the intellectual merit of the proposed project revolves around the software engineering methods used to build, improve, test, distribute, and support this high-quality robotics commons. In this project, development will focus on critical, under-served areas within ROS: flexible automation, user interfaces for non-experts, shared autonomy, robot teams, and improved platform support. Development will not focus on the algorithms available to the robotics community; rather, the intent is to provide the community with the best possible libraries and tools that embody state-of-the-art algorithms and techniques.

Just as the availability of the open source LAMP stack (Linux, Apache, MySQL, and Perl/PHP/Python) enabled the internet revolution in the 1990s, ROS and its related tools are expected to have tremendous broader impacts to the engineering community. The OSRF will provide the worldwide robotics community with freely available open source tools that will enable a generation of robotics students, developers, entrepreneurs, and enthusiasts to more quickly and easily realize their aspirations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to build what we call the "robotics commons":
a shared resource from which we all benefit (and to which we are all
welcome to contribute). Specifically, our focus is on providing the free
and open software platform that will be used to power the next generation
of robotics research, education, and product development. The work that we
have done in this project is freely available to the general public,
worldwide, to allow anyone to participate directly in the robotics
community. We believe that the availability of this platform is vital to
the continued success of the field.

During the course of the project, we invested heavily in improvements to
ROS (Robot Operating System), the widely used open source robotics
programming framework that we maintain at OSRF. Our work was divided into
two categories: creating new capabilities and new releases for the
currently used version of ROS, also known as "ROS 1"; and developing a
new version of ROS, called "ROS 2".

From 2013 to 2016, we released 3 new distributions of the ROS 1 software,
code-named Hydro, Indigo, and Kinetic (http://wiki.ros.org/Distributions).
Each distribution contains new features and capabilities that have been
implemented by our team and by other contributors. These distributions,
which the majority of users rely on for their work, are a key component of
our contribution to the community. Because of its open source nature, we
measure the impact of our work indirectly, for example via download
statistics. In July 2016, we saw a year-over-year 158% increase in the
number of downloads of ROS software. We conservatively estimate the size of
the worldwide ROS community to be in the hundreds of thousands.

Looking to the future of that community, we have spent the last few years
working on ROS 2, which provides a new implementation of the core features
of ROS. Our goal with ROS 2 are to better support users and applications
for which ROS 1 was not designed, including: multi-robot teams, real-time
control systems, and commercial product development. Our work in this
direction will culminate with the release of ROS 2 Beta 1 in mid-December
2016 (https://github.com/ros2/ros2/wiki/Roadmap#beta-1-circa-2016-12).
Based on the level of interest demonstrated thus far, we anticipate that
the Beta 1 release will attract a great deal of attention, in particular
among new and existing users at robotics companies, where there is a strong
desire to carry ROS-based robot systems all the way to market as products.

We also invest in community organizing and development, as it is the
community that makes an open source project like ROS work. Our flagship
event is ROSCon, which we held 3 times during the course of the project
(http://roscon.ros.org). The most recent edition of ROSCon, in October
2016, was a sold out event for the second year in a row, with a 20%
increase in the number of attendees, to more than 450. We also saw a 60%
increase in corporate sponsorship, which is an important indication of the
relevance of ROS to the robotics industry. All ROSCon presentations are
recorded and made freely available online after the event.
